instance_template:
cpu("FalconX"). cpu("CoreZen"). cpu("EcoMini").
gpu("TitanZ"). gpu("MidlineGT"). gpu("Pixie").
drive("FlashNova"). drive("Terabox"). drive("BudgetDisk").

cost("FalconX", 600). cost("CoreZen", 500). cost("EcoMini", 300).
cost("TitanZ", 700). cost("MidlineGT", 500). cost("Pixie", 400).
cost("FlashNova", 250). cost("Terabox", 300). cost("BudgetDisk", 150).

perf("FalconX", 125). perf("CoreZen", 115). perf("EcoMini", 90).
perf("TitanZ", 135). perf("MidlineGT", 100). perf("Pixie", 95).

generator:
1 { selected(C) : cpu(C) } 1.
1 { selected(G) : gpu(G) } 1.
1 { selected(D) : drive(D) } 1.

hard_constraints.description: Make sure the component with middle-of-the-road performance is actually the cheapest one in the box.
hard_constraints.asp_rule: :- selected(X), perf(X, PX), HI = #max { P : selected(Z), perf(Z, P) }, LO = #min { P : selected(Z), perf(Z, P) }, PX < HI, PX > LO, selected(Y), cost(X, CX), cost(Y, CY), CX > CY.

hard_constraints.description: If the CPU is a high-roller costing over 500 bucks, you can't go cheap with the Pixie GPU.
hard_constraints.asp_rule: :- selected(C), cpu(C), cost(C, V), V > 500, selected("Pixie").

hard_constraints.description: Performance spread sanity check: can't have the best and worst parts more than 50 points apart.
hard_constraints.asp_rule: :- HI = #max { P : selected(X), perf(X, P) }, LO = #min { P : selected(X), perf(X, P) }, HI > LO + 50.

hard_constraints.description: If you're rocking the FlashNova SSD, the GPU better have a performance score of at least 100.
hard_constraints.asp_rule: :- selected("FlashNova"), selected(G), gpu(G), perf(G, P), P < 100.

hard_constraints.description: Strictly two components must have a price tag higher than 300 dollars.
The GPU has to be the middle child—it can't be the top performer or the bottom performer.
hard_constraints.asp_rule:
:- selected(G), gpu(G), perf(G, PG), HI = #max { P : selected(Z), perf(Z, P) }, PG >= HI.
:- selected(G), gpu(G), perf(G, PG), LO = #min { P : selected(Z), perf(Z, P) }, PG <= LO.
